projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: ¶ The opening of the wordes of the Prophet Ioell, in his ſecond and third Chapters, reherſed by Chriſt in Mathewe .xxiiij. Marke .xiij. Luke .xxj. and by Peter Actes .ij. concerning the Signes of the laſt day. Compiled by Robert Crowley in the yeare of our Lord. M.D.XLVI. And peruſed againe by the ſame. ANNO 1566.

figure.figDesc: printer's device of John Charlewood, featuring the blazon or coat of arms of the City of Geneva, a half eagle and a key (McKerrow 136)

div.p: ¶ IMPRINTED AT LONDON by Henry Bynneman, for Iohn Charlewood, dwelling in Barbican, at the ſygne of the halfe Eagle & the Key. ANNO. 1567.

div.head: Signes and Tokens of the laſt day.

lg.l: From heauen are fallen the ſtars:
The laſt day be ſo great:
With that ſwerd yt Chriſt ſent
Peace, but to ſend a ſword,
That caſe, no man ſhall miſſe:
With the ſword muſt be ſlaine.
To giue them that are his.
His church to be trode downe?
From place to place eche day:
To this who dare ſay nay?
To ſay both yea and no.
That Chriſt bought on the trée.
To theſe things mē muſt cleue.
Great praiſe for works ſo bad.
That works muſt make vs frée,
Then ſhall we liue for aye:
Then are we like to paye.
To heare of workes at all:
All them frée that are thrall.
Of the pricke, for the one
For both hate them to death:
Some way to ſtop their breath.
Some the fleſh, ſome the ſpirite
Haue men of warre to fight:
To win much groūd by might.
As erſt hath not bene knowē:
No ſéede growes that is ſowen
So nought growth vp but wéedes.
In chaines or in a cage:
Are ſome of the baſe ſort:
Few of them do make haſt.
And hath them in a bande:
Whom Chriſt bad ſell his land,
As one that thought it deare,
And haue great ſtore of pence
Giue all and beg thy ſelfe:
It is not thine but his.
Or to ſpend it in waſte:
Will call for it in haſte.
So that they muſt be ſkant:
I thinke no man can tell:
The poore know that ful well.
And brought them vp ſo hie,
To him nor to his heyres.
Vſe they not to ſay ſo?
From that ye ſée vs do.
We ſhal haue none at all.
Of lay men nor of clarkes:
And beare of Chriſt the name:
And liue as Chriſt hath taught:
Shall teache you all full well.
To learne a point of the law.
He will haue the tenth fell:
And with Gods part to mocke.
So that he pay the ſumme.
But God for colde ſhall fréeſe.
If that they pleaſe him well:
To ſpend at their owne will:
That gaue them him to kéepe.
Whom thou haſt in a fée:
To ſpeake one word for thée.
For that they haue miſſe meld.
The rope in hand to take:
And helpe the wall to ſcale:
No man may be their bale.
To them that giue the ſaute.
By fire to iudge the land,
And all games of the ſame:
Where he ſhall ride or go.
And kéepe a brace of houndes:
To hang men by the throtes.
One voide of all Gods grace.
For prieſts that do them ſerue:
Then for their rents they ſend.
If that he may ought winne:
That is of the prieſtes kinne.
Some ſixe or ſeuen I trowe:
Spendeth not ten pound a yere
Whiles ye his taile will wagge.
To rid the way at néede:
That can make the beſt ſpéede.
They muſt ſpare for no coſt.
And take all that they can.
To cap and knée full lowe:
To them they do not knowe.
With mo bagges to the mill:
And yet they will beg ſtill.
Muſt helpe or all is loſte:
To take the charge of cure,
To ſpend all at their wil:
And freſh cuppes for to fil.
Haue pence to ſcoure their throtes.
Chriſtes bloud to bie thē drinke
Would ſel mine to I thinke.
Their gains wold be but ſmal:
Euen for the dregges and all.
That all men ſhall be glad:
The good way from the bad.
To till it is no boote.
And luſt for foode to call.
As would haue fed vs found.
Shepe, as ſoone as the olde.
That in Chriſt put their truſt:
Their babes to waſhe men vſe,
And ſet them on his lap.
By they haue liued ſeuē yeres:
And ſay they haue no peares.
No ſtewes ſo full of vice.
The ſéede that God thée gaue.
To be drowned in the ſea,
Should learne to ſinne at thée.
To teach them the Lordes wil:
For thē that Chriſt hath bought
If God wil be my guide:
That no man ſhal it hide.
Much more thē doth them good.
This bloud hath made vs frée:
From ſinne that we may take:
The fleſh in déede or thought,
The fleſh, death, hel and ſinne:
Will be tride to be iuſt.
But death ſhall flée them fro:
To thinke Chriſt made vs frée:
Hath ſet vs all at large:
To lay ought to our charge.
When he ſhal iudge vs all:
Be not like Peter and Paule.
Through Chriſt that do not ſtil
The fleſh, to do Gods wil.
All one, this is no nay,
To haue Gods ſpirite in vs:
By no meanes put our truſt.
To all that wil worke vice:
From their olde ſinne to riſe.
But ſeke God and his will:
In myer vp to the head:
His worde and worke his will:
Which thing it doth in déede:
With the foode of the ſoule:
And houre of our firſt birthe:
What plague can be like this?
In prayer, that it may pleaſe
Should be hāged by the throte.
So long as he is ledde,
The valley to make them fatte:
To féede his flocke eche day,
To bye a flocke of ſhéepe:
That wil take them to kéepe.
He hath to féede them on,
May be found in this land:
The court, or ſome lordes place:
Where they ſet one to ſpie,
To try what may be made:
And tenthes due to the king:
So long as ought is lafte.
For that you may be ſure:
As growes in the field wide.
Be them that flée vs fro:
To ſaue vs from our foe.
By meanes that they do finde.
Do ſay they wil vs féede:
At all times when we néede.
Vs, as they do but ſelde:
As few ſicke men haue felde.
Whoſe names I dare not tell:
The flocke of Chriſt to ſell.
That Chriſtes flocke be not bought.
To leade vs in and out:
Of this worlde will not doubt.
Of gods word with their flock:
And ſée him go ſo bright:
His foote both day and night.
No cloud ſhal duſke their ſight:
Grace to ſée vs his flocke,
That haue writ of the ſame:
When they ſéeke a way out.
That is nigh to the place:
We might looke for a beaſt:
Liue then, as you do thinke?
And not to whord in ſtore:
A poore man and a king:
Are firſt gotten, And then borne,
Both like, both waile and wéepe,
A like both crie, A like both lie,
A like both wake and ſléepe.
For by his birth, He is but erth,
All die and fall to duſt,
This thing to bée, True ye may ſée,
In their graues if you luſt.
Whē they rot in ye ground:
And ſay, when did we ſée:
Say, get you hence from me,
Euen than was I, In miſery,
How harde they fare, Taking no care
Whō they ſhould ayde by right.
Which are had in great price:
And ſtarue for lacke of foode:
Much more than doth you good.
Thā that you muſt nedes ware:
To halte, blinde, and to lame.
Let ſuch worke wc their handes.
May haue grace to vſe it.
Is more than all the land.
But few ſhall mende their liues.
In Gods worde ſhould be found
Muſt néedes graunt that there lieth:
But when the Sunne is cleare,
When Gods worde is in ſight.
By day walke in the light:
whoſe works ſhine in the night.
To ſhine in the world rounde.
Theſe will be tried at the laſt:
And yet wroght Chriſt much wo.
Was cauſe that they did this,
To ſpeake till ſome were fride.
Men praiſed God in our king:
Had brought to paſſe this thing.
Yet are their mindes the ſame:
And ſome haue cure of ſoules,
From thē that dranke in boules.
To ſée of them great ſtore:
To plucke vp this fowle ſinne.
Shal make ought for your part.
No meane to mende their liues.
And hath the gift to preache:
With ſuch giftes as they get.
To preach if that they can,
Of gods word taught ful plainly
One ſhall not miſſe to ſpeake:
To lye prieſtes do not reake.
Say they, than we be now:
Saith Chriſt I giue you now:
Euen as I haue loued you.
Shall be knowen to all men:
The truth you may be ſure:
Will count eche prieſt a wretch.
Is all thing that they do.
This day, what Prince or King:
To get all that they may.
Landes, was giuen to eche one:
To holde in their owne handes:
Shall not be worth a ſtraw:
And giue me eare a while:
For no man though they can.
So they do no man wrong:
Which of you can rule beſt.
And God ſhall giue you hier.
When Chriſt ſhall iudge vs all:
As the frée doth the thrall.
At the beames of the ſunne.
As we may iudge by ſight.
And they wil not make ſtrange:
Both at full and at change.
And that halfe is aye bright:
It be out of our ſight.
From vs is toward the Sunne:
All thinges are in good plight:
As a théefe in the night.
Him whoſe houſe he wil breake
Shall not lie in our necke.
That Chriſt meaneth in this place:
To whō God giueth not grace.
On them is from the ſunne:
Sheweth you to be the light:
Be he wiſe man or daw.
Let the knaues liue no more:
That ſet by vs no ſtore?
what ſhould we paſſe for lawes?
That dare not ſtrike a ſtroke?
That feareth a fray to make.
That the Moone is all blood:
Light of this worlde to be:
The ſpirite thus ſay may we.
His courſe, hath giuen vs light:
And would be called the light:
They ſhall ſay and not do:
Nor for their miſſe be wo.
Are of Chriſt called the light
So much as theſe men do:
Of Chriſt whom they cleane to.
As they, none paſſe leſſe howe
I thinke is right well knowne:
Doth not ſhine in mens ſight:
As ought to ſhine full bright.
The ſignes of the laſt day:
And then we ſhall not miſſe:

div.p: IMPRINTED AT LONdon by Henry Bynneman for Iohn Charlewood, dwelling in Barbican, at the ſigne of the halfe Eagle and the Key.
